awd_titl_txt: NCS-FO: Collaborative Research: The evolutionary origins of leadership in chimpanzees: from individual minds to collective action
awd_abstract_narration:
Leadership is crucial for effective cooperation, especially in large and complex groups. Yet there is an empirical and theoretical gap in our understanding of the individual-level processes underpinning leadership and the group-level consequences of leadership. How does the cognition of individual leaders translate into coordinated group action in the real world?  This project proposes using chimpanzees as a new model of human-like leadership to better understand the evolutionary origins of our own leadership patterns. We will bridge the gap between individual- and group-level phenomena by conducting matched research with semi-free ranging chimpanzees living in a sanctuary where we can do detailed assessments of cognition, and with chimpanzees living in the wild where we can look at complex group behavior in a natural setting. By matching datasets across these two contexts, we will be able to see how individual cognitive process translate into group action. While humans are thought to be uniquely able to establish leadership through prestige and collaboration instead of just pure physical domination, chimpanzees are our closest living relative, also show variation in how individuals obtain and maintain status in their groups. This project will therefore illuminate the evolutionary origins of human leadership, and also set a new agenda in evolutionary cognitive science for studying cognition in the wild. Training, education, and outreach from elementary school through to graduate school will be integrated throughout the project both domestically and abroad. As part of this proposal, we will develop a leadership module for children, using animal models to demonstrate different forms of leadership. We will implement this module through outreach at local schools and museums in the US and in 16 primary schools in Uganda. Undergraduates and high school students in the US will gain hand-on research experience through internships and in coursework. Two postdoctoral researchers and a graduate student will further gain international research experiences in the course of the project. This integrated approach to research and education will train a new generation of evolutionary cognitive scientists and disseminate primate research to the public.

This project has three specific aims. The first aim is to identify individual leaders (those with outsized influence) in natural social groups across multiple contexts of behavior including dominance rank, initiation of group movements, resource acquisition, within-group mediation and inter-group aggression. The second aim is to create leadership profiles by characterizing individual variation in the cognitive, behavioral, and physiological mechanisms of leaders across these contexts. At the sanctuary, 100+ chimpanzees across 5 social groups will be assayed for cognition (including social cognition, cooperation, and executive function); temperament; behavior (aggression and affiliation), and physiology (hormones and body size) to predict leadership. At the field site, similar assessments will be made of temperament, behavior, and physiology, drawing on a longitudinal database with 30 years of data on 150 wild chimpanzees. These data will be used to test the hypothesis that there are distinct pathways to leadership in chimpanzees, with intimidation-based and cooperative strategies being the most important, but knowledge and motivation anchoring some forms of leadership. The final aim is to understand how variation in leadership styles shapes the outcomes of collective action by examining several short-and long-term metrics of leadership success, including group cohesion, rewards received, and biological outcomes like reproductive success that can only be studied in the wild. This project will bridge individual-level and group-level perspectives on cognition, behavior, and physiology by leveraging the strengths of two natural populations of chimpanzees. The project will match experimental and observational techniques across sites on a scale never previously done, and will develop chimpanzees as a new model for human leadership.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Goals & Activities: The University of Michigan, in collaboration with Tufts University and the University of New Mexico, generated novel findings on the cognitive, behavioral and physiological foundations of leadership in chimpanzees, humans’ closest evolutionary relatives. The results of this work shed light on the evolutionary origins for unique patterns of prestige and social power in humans. While leadership in most nonhuman animals is strongly dependent on the ability to physically dominate others, humans are exceptional in the degree to which leadership may arise from other routes, involving diverse individual strategies and their associated cognitive and physiological mechanisms. Our research aimed to identify alternative strategies for social influence across multiple domains of chimpanzee behavior. We used a novel design to measure individual variation in cognitive strategies and connect this with naturalistic observations of social behavior in semi-free-ranging chimpanzees living in African sanctuaries, as well as extensive observations and matched cognitive experiments in a wild group. To achieve these aims, we designed a novel battery of experimental tasks and indexed individual differences in cognitive performance in 90 sanctuary chimpanzees; implemented a novel behavioral data collection protocol in sanctuaries directly modeled on wild chimpanzee data protocols resulting in ~14,000 ten-minute focals; and collected 400 urine samples to assess hormones that have been associated with temperament, social tolerance, and leadership styles in humans. In the wild, the collaborative team collected 13,000 hours of naturalistic field observations of social behavior at the Kibale National Park, Uganda; collected more than 1700 urine samples and analyzed existing biospecimens; and implemented a novel program of matched cognitive experiments for a subset of the cognitive measures.

Outcomes: Whereas aggressive competition has been recognized as the primary determinant of social status in chimpanzees, our research revealed that chimpanzee leadership may also hinge on flexible cognitive and behavioral skills, and further that chimpanzees may show alternative forms of leadership in individuals who are not at the top of the dominance hierarchy. Our observational data collection in sanctuaries allowed us to measure dominance status and group social interactions in these populations as in wild populations. We also validated a new cognitive task battery, and characterized individual variation in chimpanzee cognitive performance across cognitive control, social cognition, decision-making, and temperament. We found that cognitive control formed a distinct cluster of competency, and varied with social dominance status across individuals. Third, we developed metrics of leadership in other domains such as hunting and tool use. For example, we characterized individual variation in wild chimpanzee tool use and found that females appear to be both more likely to use certain kinds of tools and also influence tool use in others. Our study also helped explain sexually-differentiated patterns of social behavior and dominance in chimpanzees, as females were more social and have greater power in sanctuary groups where ecological and energetic constraints on female behavior are relaxed. Finally, our team developed novel approaches for characterizing individual variation in hormonal profiles and associated this variation with social behavioral styles exhibited by wild chimpanzees, as well as with performance of sanctuary chimpanzees on cognitive tasks. While human phenomena such as prestige-based leadership are not fully expressed in apes, the advances from this study identify some shared features and mechanisms associated with leadership behavior in chimpanzees and humans and localize these features in the unusual degree of sociality and cooperation exhibited by both species. The funding resulted in publications in high-impact journals including Science, Cognition, and Developmental Science, Journal of Experimental Psychology.

Broader impacts: The collaboration enabled researchers to gain interdisciplinary training and cross-mentorship across the three institutions which collectively trained 3 postdocs, 6 graduate students, over 40 undergraduates, and 6 high school students. The principal investigators and trainees developed the Primate Learning in Action website (https://sites.lsa.umich.edu/primatelearning/) to disseminate information about primate cognition, behavior, and conservation at a range of knowledge levels spanning grad school to professional scientists, including hands-on data science and statistical analysis modules using real data; methods for observing and recording chimpanzee behavior; and activities focused on animal leadership. The study further supported dozens of Ugandan field researchers and support staff at the sanctuaries and the Kibale Chimpanzee Project to coordinate the daily data collection, providing training to carry out study protocols and broader professionalization opportunities through peer mentorship across performance sites and community engagement. The investigators served continuing roles as collaborators and advisors for donor-supported partner projects that serve the educational and conservation needs associated with our research presence in rural Uganda, including the Kasiisi Schools Project, the Kibale Snare Removal Project, and the Chimpanzee Health Intervention and Monitoring Program. These programs have collectively reduced the occurrence of poaching and resulting injuries to chimpanzees and improved attitudes to wildlife both directly, through programming in 16 local schools, and indirectly, by linking community development and educational programming to the conservation of wildlife.
